title: How should I write a contraction of 'seems to have' which the speaker pronounces as 'seems to of?' The speaker is well educated and would not use 'of' in this phrase. - Quora

response.answer_text: Your question’s wording is confusing. You say the speaker pronouns it as “seems to of” but then say they are well educated and would not use “of”. Which is it? Do they or don’t they? Let’s assume it’s the latter. If that’s the case, what about using the standard contraction for have (‘ve)? So it would be seems to’ve. That’s what we do it in other scenarios where the contraction isn’t terribly common, e.g. shouldn’t’ve.

I don’t know why the feel the need to write this as a contraction. There is no standard contraction for this. You write “seems to have.” If you really feel the need to write a contraction to show how the speaker is pronouncing it, you would write “seems to’ve.” However, this is not standard English. Almost all English speakers would pronounce it the same way and everyone understands what they mean.

Are you transcribing what someone said? Write the full word: It seems to have happened. Most readers will pronounce this as “seems to uv” and the word “of” also happens to be pronounced “uv”—but that’s just a coincidence. Unless you are doing a phonetic transcription, there’s no reason to write “seems ta’ve” or “gonna’ or “hafta” even though that’s how *all English speakers* actually say them (or say’em.)

He’s probably saying “seems to’ve” kind of like “would’ve.” In other words, he’s not really saying “to of;” he’s just slurring the “have” to the point that it’s unrecognizable. It’s slightly lazy speech but very common. That said, people frequently write “would of” and “should of” etc. which is understandable but still incorrect.

Seems to me I might've done something like this when speaking in a hurry. It's trickier in a short context like you've given. Not sure, but seems t'uh've taken a rapid pass through of sounds. " T' " sounds like "tuh". It's a little easier if a word ends in "t" and a "have" comes after. Although, I think I've heard "after having gone" rendered as "after've gone" leaving out the subject.

Seems to ‘ ve maybe. Spoken english us getting a bit sloppy these days but this is how language develops. We would not be able to understand the english spoken in the middle ages and that was only 800 years ago. One wonders what it will be like in 800 years time.
Unless you are writing a play and the way the character speaks is important, you don’t. Write what the character says and let the reader supply their pronounciation in their own mind.
appears. She appears to have lost her hat because she keeps placing her hand on her head and looking around.
